page.title: 17MADELEY STAFFS : WILD LIFE
page.content: In a chiefly dairying area,the hedgerow mainly survive,their timbers oak with some ash.There are several copses of sycamore,birch,horsechestnut.Many wild flowers appear in the lane verges.In at least 2 sites the spotted orchid grows; the dog violet & wood anemone,also.One farmer leave untouched a small patch where primroses grow profusely.Orange tip butterflies feed in several nettle beds.Brown trout have reappeared in the Lea,attracting a pair of heron.Several mallard & moorhen nest near its banks. Most farms house a few bats.In the area are numerous rabbits,magpies,pigeons & grey squirrels.French partridge,escaped from a wildlife park,breed freely & are seen,in winter,in coveys of around 30. The Deer Centre,opened in 1985,a scheme mainly funded by the MSC,to reduce deer road accidents by conservation work, educational programmes & exhibitions.
